captions.text:
The Temple is by far one of the most recognizable
stages in all of “Smash History” due to

the fact that it has been in EVERY incarnation
of Super Smash Bros. outside of the original

N64 and the 3DS versions of the games. In
Melee, it serves at the home stage for characters

in both the Zelda and Fire Emblem franchises
due to the fact that Marth and Roy DID NOT

have a stage of their own. Yet, where DOES
the Temple originate from? Well luckily for

you guys, your friendly neighborhood TrailerDrake
is here for a Smash History lesson!

For the most part, the Temple is based on
the many palaces from The Legend of Zelda

II: The Adventure of Link. Still, isn’t
it odd that the stage is called Temple instead

of Palace? The reason behind that is because
they’re actually called temples in the Japanese
version of Zelda II!

It’s also worth noting that Zelda II is
the only game in the Zelda franchise to be

a 2D platformer… Okay, except for the CDI
games, but those really don’t count… However,

this could just be a coincidence due to Smash
Bros. is a fighting game, but you get the

exact same perspective of characters as you
do of Link in Zelda II. So that’s pretty
neat.

Enough stalling though, let’s take a look
at the stage itself! The entrances to each

palace in Zelda II are identical. Walk up
a couple of steps, pass a statue, and go down

an elevator. At the far left side of the Temple,
it appears that we get just that, a couple

of steps, the corridor that normally houses
the statue, and a tunnel leading down to an

underground area. Oddly enough, I have seen
reports all around the internet claim that

in the beta version of Super Smash Bros. Melee,
the Temple stage originally had an elevator
in place of the underground tunnel.

However, the only visual proof that I have
seen of the elevator is this “mysterious

elevator” is this super small split second
glimpse of the Temple’s beta form in Super

Smash Brother Melee’s special movie. The
elevator was most likely removed to help balance

the game, but that’s fine, because now we
have this super… amazing… SECRET TUNNEL!

The palaces in Zelda II are notorious for
being large and expansive which is appropriate

considering the fact that the Temple is by
far, the largest stage in Melee! So how do

you represent these MASSIVE dungeons in Zelda
II’s weird overworld? Well, with this icon

of course! Now take a look at the backround
at the top of the Temple stage and tell me

what’s there. Yup! It’s the exact same
icon, brought to life in glorious 3D!

Still, that’s not the only background building
easter egg in the Temple! Take a look at the

righthand side of the stage. The background
seems to contain a building that looks REMARKABLY

similar to the Temple of Time of Ocarina of
Time!

You guys might have noticed that I haven’t
talked about any of the platforms at the bottom

of the stage and honestly, that’s because
I can’t seem to find anything that harkens

back to any of the original Zelda games. HOWEVER,
this bottom area is notorious in the Smash

Bros. community and was even dubbed the “Fight
Club” by Nintendo Power, but why is it named

that? Oddly enough, it’s NOT because the
movie/book Fight Club started out as a literal

underground organization, but it’s actually
because battles down here let you really rack

up damage percentages! You see with environment
like that of Fight Club, players with high

percentages get smacked around with less chance
of being blasted off. Take it from me, if

you’re starting to get hurt in the Temple,
make your way down or Hyrule Jump your way
to the Fight Club.

Wait… you guys don’t know about the Hyrule
Jump?! This is one of my favorite techniques!

The Hyrule Jump is a great tactic to put some
distance between you and your enemies. Run

off the righthand side of the upper level
and maneuver yourself onto the small platform

at the bottom of the stage. This move has
saved my skin on more than one occasion!

Aaaaanyway, enough about all of that and let’s
get back to analyzing!

There’s text written all across the stage
in Hylian. There have been multiple Hylian

alphabets over the years and the Temple is
a great example to prove this. In Melee, the

text looks reminiscent of that seen in Ocarina
of Time, but it’s not. Nintendo officially

released a decoder for the language used in
Ocarina of Time and while visually similar,
the language seen in the Temple is NOT this.

But don’t worry! In Super Smash Bros. for
3DS and Wii U, the text is actually changed

to the language that first appeared in the
Wind Waker.

In order to translate this, we need to first
convert the Hylian into Japanese hiragana

and katakana and that gives us スマツシユ・ブラザーズ.
So what’s that in English? (SUPER SMAAAAAAASH
BROTHERS!)

The Omega version of this stage has you fighting
on a floating island with the Temple broken

into chunks in the background. Yet, take a
look at the pieces back there. There’s only

two chunks present. So what happened to the
third one? Nobody knows.

Anyway guys, that’s all I have got for today,
but if you liked me branching out into stages,

PLEASE let me know in the comments and I might
just do more. Still, if you haven’t gotten

sick of my annoying voice yet, you can always
just mosey on over to my personal channel

and check out my Unpopular Nintendo Opinions
or you can just stick around here and watch

my recent analysis on Bowser and Bowser Jr.
Still, as always, make sure to like, subscribe,

and tell me what characters and or stages,
you’d like to see ME analyze next!

title: Smash History: Hyrule Temple (Super Smash Bros 3DS and Wii U Level Analysis)
